captions.text:
SCOTT: I was going to buy a bike
when I was at college,
and my mom had a [BLEEP]
fit.

She flipped out and basically
said if I bought a bike in
college, I was excommunicated.

She would never talk
to me again, never
help me with anything.
WES: This is Joshua Tree.

That's Scott from Cleveland
CycleWorks.
Welcome to the RideApart.

I just spent all day
riding a [BLEEP]
Talk to me about that.
SCOTT: You had fun.
WES: I had fun.

It doesn't make any
horsepower.

It doesn't have flashing
graphics.
SCOTT: No.

GRANT: You can't do
a burnout on it.

WES: I can't do a
burnout on it.

SCOTT: You can't do
a burnout on it.

WES: Mostly because
I'm a [BLEEP].
SCOTT: He can.
I can.
But you can't.
WES: Well, I'm special.
GRANT: Yes.

SCOTT: You're special,
that's true.
GRANT: Yeah, he is, yes.
WES: I'm a special person.

SCOTT: I'm from the Midwest,
I'm from Cleveland.

And distinctly, Cleveland's a
working-class sort of city.

You don't have people that are
trying to prove to people that
they make $1 million a year.

There's people that just
legitimately want to ride a

cool bike that they
can afford.

And for that sort of person,
our bike makes sense.
It's not a OCC sort of bike.

But it's a cool bike you can
even be proud to ride.

The whole idea is someone that's
buying our bikes, they
can work on it.

We have manuals on how
to adjust the valves.
It's a very simple motor.
Four valve dual overhead cam--

you can't touch it, you have
to take it to a dealer.

The overhead valve motor, if you
need to adjust the valves,
you can do it in the bike.

The idea behind what we're
trying to do is you're riding,

you need to do a little
of maintenance,
you could do it yourself.

You can adjust the chain,
adjust the valves.

It's a whole concept, it's
different than what's been

going on in the motorcycle
industry.

It's like, I went to school to
change the world, but you can
only change the door handle.

And I'm using the door handle
as a metaphor for everything

that's wrong with the
whole car industry.

GRANT: I think you're
absolutely right.

I did this conference once in
Pittsburgh with JT back in

February, and we had done
the [INAUDIBLE].

The guy who spoke before us
designed the door handle on
the new Ford Mustang.

And his entire lecture was about
his job as a designer

with Ford, and now he
designed the [BLEEP]

door handle on the
new Ford Mustang.

And we basically got up there,
and we'd been drinking the
entire time.

So we started through with
the bottle of whiskey.

We were like phew, I'm glad to
not be hearing about that guy

anymore because that
sounds [BLEEP]
terrible.

SCOTT: We looked at what you
needed to make a legitimate
bike in the US.

And what you need is you need to
be able to do short jaunts
on the highway--

any of those situations where
you really want to
power pass the cars.

As we progressed, the whole idea
behind the company is to

make riding accessible
to more people.

GRANT: OK, let's talk about
that profession.

Where do you see CCW going
as its models develop?

SCOTT: We're always going to
be a value-driven company.

So you'll never see
us trying to be
Indian or Harley Davidson.
For me, that's been done.

And if you look at
Excelsior-Henderson, or

there's been so many companies
that have tried to be Harley
Davidson and failed.

Because Harley's Harley,
they're here.

They exist, and there's no need
for another company to
become Harley Davidson.

People are always going to buy
Harley because it is Harley.

So for me as an American
company, trying to become
that, it has no value.

WES: I have a hard time with
the lack of suspension.

I'm bitching because I bitch,
but my ass is not sore.

The bike handled great, it
was great in corners.

I rode a Victory Judge, which
is like a $18,000, 1800cc

ridiculous chopper,
two weeks ago.

This has more ground clearance,
better handling,

better brakes, a
better engine.
It's a little less shiny.

I feel like my penis
is a little bit
smaller when I ride it.
SCOTT: It is.

So the whole idea behind Tha
Heist, which is the bike that

you rode, is it basically gives
you the presence of a

much bigger bike for
a lot less money.
So if you go to a bike night--

Cleveland, we have a Quaker
Steak & Lube.

That's the big bike night, you
could find 1,500-2,000 bikes
on a nice night.

You take this bike to a Quaker
Steak, and you go to a bike

night, and basically, people
have no idea what it is.

They think it's a $8,000, maybe
$10,000, old Harley.

WES: With the proportions,
the engine doesn't look
small in the frame.

It looks like a nice,
big, chunky engine.

And you park that thing, and it
generally does look like a
bad ass motorcycle.
SCOTT: Well, here's the thing.

So the bike is physically a
little bit longer, it's a

little bit bigger than
a Harley Sportster.

It's not a big, stretched
out, custom--
it's a bike that's proportioned
very well to the rider.

You're a big guy,
how big are you?
SCOTT: So you're 6'2".

WES: I don't feel out
of place on it.

It's actually comfortable and
natural, there's not a huge
reach to the bars.

The seat is comfortable,
there's not a huge
reach to the pegs.

SCOTT: You're on the upper
echelon of someone that would
ride that bike.

6'2", you're pretty big
for what that bike is.

But the whole idea is it's an
affordable bike, it kind of

has the presence of a much
more expensive bike.

And the way we get there is
by using that 250 motor.

So the 250 is what really
makes it affordable.

We basically took a very simple
motor, it's overhead
valve, it has rockers.

It's easy to work on, and
it has a lot of torque.

In my company, design is the
number one, it's the most
important thing.

Our bikes are inexpensive,
but people desire them.

It's quote unquote
"entry-level," but it doesn't
look entry-level--

there's a difference
through design.

It's appealing, it's a whole
different concept.

The US was built on people
dreaming, and that's lost.

It's lost, especially when I
have 98% of the people I'm

telling I'm going to start a
motorcycle company, 98% of

those people telling
me it's impossible.

This is America, nothing
is impossible.

I mean really, nothing's
impossible.

I was so happy, and it took
me to get fired from a

comfortable job to be able to
have the balls to do this.

comments.text:
I might be too quick to judge & name call...If they have plenty of 
replacement parts & a warranty & the bikes are quality made even though 
manufactured in china. Then I don't see a problem. But if they are the same 
junk $2,500 Chinese bikes you can order yourself online. Then people 
deserve to know you can buy the same bike for $500-$1,000 cheaper. The CCW 
videos seem very misleading, they give the impression that the bikes are 
all built in Cleveland Oh by a small group of guys. That's what irritates 
me. But Harley Davidson sold out & still tries to use the whole made in USA 
were #1 marketing crap so.....﻿
comments.author: Mike Brink

comments.text:
As Sean Penn said in fast times at ridgemont high "Those guys are fags" In 
reference to cleveland cycle werks.  If you don't believe Yamaha SR650 just 
look up Chinese motorcycles on the web & check out sites like 
scooterdepot.us   or saferwholesale.com for your self. If u want a cheap 
chinese bike why not just order one from china for $2,000 yourself, instead 
of paying these posers $3,300. Now I know why Yamaha SR650 hates CCW they 
just buy a bike from China for $1,500-$2,000 & slap CCW emblem on it & sell 
it for $3,300. I believe after looking up 250cc Chinese motorcycles online, 
that Cleveland cycle werks is a complete joke ran buy posers.﻿
comments.author: Mike Brink

comments.text:
So I'm a recent college graduate and I've always wanted to get an old 
school muscle car, but after seeing this I borderline want to get one of 
these bikes. Cars were always my thing, but man. Those two bikes in the 
video look super nice to ride and fun. Which in the end what could I ask 
for more? Great job and I am definitely gonna be looking for a dealer near 
me. Currently in New Orleans LA. So any info would be appreciated.﻿
comments.author: Guatemalanferlife Ya Heard

comments.text:
+Guatemalanferlife Ya Heard If you live in the US and ride a Rebel, you had 
better be a dyke (lesbian) or have a sense of humor to take all the razzing 
you'll get for riding one. They are an excellent, reliable motorcycle as 
far as I know. Just change any fluid(s) regularly (oil/filter if equipped) 
 A very simple and easy to maintain motorcycle. By all means, do NOT buy 
any mode of transportation from China! It's all junk...at least what's 
exported.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 What is your thoughts on the Honda Rebel? Because I did what 
you said and looked up some reviews and whatnot and I'm definitely not as 
interested as I was at one point. I don't really want something that goes 
super fast because I'm not running highway really ever. It's just a from 
home to school to eat out with friends and just whatever else the city may 
offer
comments.author: Guatemalanferlife Ya Heard

comments.text: +Mike Brink Can't get parts for them though.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 Maybe I'm too quick to judge. If they can prove that they are 
quality built machines and have repair parts available & a warranty. Then I 
guess I shouldn't call them posers or fags.But if they are ordering $2,000 
bikes from china  slapping a CCW logo on em & selling em for $3,300 Then 
people should know u can just order one of these bikes yourself from china 
for $2,000.
comments.author: Mike Brink

comments.text: +Mike Brink Anybody who wastes money on one deserves their fate.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 Not everything made in China is total junk. But if what you 
say is true it's best to run the other way. Now I'm curious to see the 
factory in China & who actually works there. I can't remember the name but 
I seen these 250cc bike's advertised online that were made in china for 
like $2,500 a piece.They had a crotch rocket model-a chopper-& a  bobber 
model.That were very similar to these CCW bikes. That's probably who makes 
these Cleveland bikes.They buy em off china wholesale for $2,000 a piece, 
slap some CCW emblems on em & sell em for $3,300 I'm guessing you could 
just order the same bike from China for $2,500 & put ur own CCW emblems on 
instead of buying 1 from Cleveland for $3,300. Ok I found it look at 
www.safewholesale.com It pretty much proves what you're saying. CCW is a 
joke... If the quality of a Chinese bike was as good as any other & u could 
get parts it'd be a different story.
comments.author: Mike Brink

comments.text:
+Guatemalanferlife Ya Heard Go back and read all my posts. These bikes are 
made in China by slave labor children. The quality SUCKS! Look up: 
"Cleveland, nothing but Problems: Customer critique of warranty, 
manufacture quality and service of Cleveland Cyclewerks." These bikes are 
NOT made in Cleveland, Ohio. Sure. You go ahead and buy one. Just be 
warned, if you break it, you're stuck. Parts aren't available.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:

comments.author: Matrick Galius

comments.text:
If anyone cares, these bikes are made in China and the "Cleveland" name is 
added here to make you think you're buying an American-made bike.
Forget it. They're one of over 200 makes of Chinese motorcycles but 
the only one exported.
You'll never find parts if needed.
Go to: "Cleveland, nothing but problems: customer critique of warranty, 
manufacture quality and service of Cleveland Cyclewerks" for full details.
I've personally chatted with the "owner" a "Scott Colosimo" who claims the 
bike is made here in the states.
His VP, a "Brett" is quoted as saying, "These are just Chinese pieces of 
shit" and that Scott is just a "..vacuum cleaner designer".
DON'T KILL THE MESSENGER!
The Daniel Gallant who posted the "Cleveland, nothing but problems" was 
threatened with a lawsuit by Scott for only reporting the poor quality and 
poor treatment by Scott & Company.

I wish these bikes WERE nice, quality and reliable bikes. Hell, I'd buy tow 
or three!
Until then, I'll just stick with my old, reliable 1979 Yamaha SR500 with 
it's potent 650 stroker engine.﻿
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:

comments.author: twan mager

comments.text:
+Trevor Jameson Honda Rebels are great beginner bikes and perfect for 
anyone who just wants to putt around on for fun. Just change the oil once 
in a while.
I'd only ride one on a bet.
I recall the parts manager at John Deere Industrial (the yellow J.D's) who 
bought something like a Rebel. It had cogged tooth belt final drive.
Well, after work on just about any given day, all us mechanics and some of 
the parts guys would gather out back and drink beer and bullshit. "Poncho", 
the parts manager joined us a few times. He had his little bike once and I 
asked if I could ride it. I, of course was fortified with some beer and had 
at it. He cringed when I did a few donuts on some dirt-covered asphalt. 
Then I tried doing a "burnout" on that surface. I unloaded the clutch at 
high revs and the cogged belt slipped making this incredibly loud sound 
similar to the tearing of canvas. Ooops! I then returned it to him.
One day he showed up with a black eye and swollen face. He had dumped it 
and hit his face on a curb. His wife made him get rid of it.
Nice call on the XR350R. Great bike. Almost up there with Yamaha's XT500!

Yeah, toss money on any Chinese bike and you're doomed. Maybe get a couple 
rides out of it before some irreplaceable part breaks or falls of.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 I'm afraid I'm going to have to agree with you. I was at a 
Honda shop picking up a new pair of gloves last weekend, and they had two 
Honda Rebels.. one in red, and one in black. Just for fun I sat on one. 
They are nice little bikes, and don't pretend to be something they are not. 
I bet they will run forever, too. I say that, because I have a 1985 Honda 
XR350R that was my Dad's, and now it's mine, and it's still in excellent 
condition. Never a single problem with it, ever!    So why anyone would 
THROW money away on a Chinese piece of junk, I have absolutely no clue.
comments.author: Trevor Jameson

comments.text:
+Jeff S You got it, Jeff. I see old Rebels running around all the time. 
Usually, Dykes are on them but hey, at least they're riding instead of 
pushing one of these miserable CycleWipe shitpiles..
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
You could go buy a new Honda that would last decades for what you'd pay for 
these ChinkChoppers. Try a Honda shop first.
You'd not be "laughing" when you rode one of these for 50 miles and not 
more.
Google "Cleveland, nothing but problems: Customer Critique of Warranty..." 
etc.

I'm willing to bet you'd never afford a WalMart Razor judging by your 
child-like grammatical skills, kid:
"dowing" (doing) "costum" (custom) "fore" (for) "poeple" (people) "fore" 
(before) "coeast" (cost) "isent" (isn't) "bed" (bet) "part's" (parts) 
"havinf" (having) That's enough. My brain is starting to hurt! Man, you're 
so dumb I almost want to cry for and about you but maybe this message will 
encourage you to go back to school.

Parts are NOT available for these since there's no dealerships. You send 
them money, they send you a crate shipped directly from Chinkland.

You should have known.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
Why make up "facts" to support these? You can get a Honda CBR250R or 
Rebel that is a way better bike than these things are for about 1000.00 
more. It will have parts support, a warranty, and readily available service 
locations.
comments.author: Jeff S

comments.text:
That is what motorcycles should be, simple, reliable and do your own 
maintenance. I think there is a new generation of riders that say the 
simpler the better. Fuck all the gadgets we just want to ride. I have a 
1996 Tdm 850 it is with me since the year it was made but sometimes I just 
think it has much plastic and power and I am looking for a smaller bike, 
where can I buy one of these?﻿
comments.author: Antonio Faustino

comments.text:
Where the hell do you get parts for these turds? Had a buddy that had one 
and it started smoking at 300 miles. The cylinder walls were so rough it 
ate the piston and rings. And to add insult to injury there wasn't an 
oversize piston available. In my opinion worthless. That's just my opinion 
so don't get bent outta shape. Yamaha is the only way to go. Or Suzuki..﻿

comments.text:
To me its real simple... If you want the best cruiser and money is not a 
issue. Buy a Harley.
If you want something that handles like a extension of your body and has 
awesome brakes. Buy a jap sport bike.
But in the end if you want to own a motorcycle and have fun, buy whatever 
feels good to you. Test ride a bunch of bike and if you land on one of this 
^ cheap bikes, it feels good, you have a big smile while riding it and it's 
in your budget then fucking buy it!.



﻿

there. It's all subjective, but that region is something else. It borders 
the Great Lakes, is in the eastern time zone, and seemingly connects the 
eastern states with the true midwest.

comments.author: David Andrews

comments.text:
I don't see why people are out to talk shit about these bikes. There's a 
couple of guys that have gone to almost every comment and said why they 
think these bikes are crap. Does talking shit about a bike make you feel 
better about yourself? If you don't like these bikes, so what? There's 
bikes that I don't like. If someone thinks these bikes are crap, then go 
look at something else. I mean if someone thinks they look bad as hell on 
them, then good for them. Isn't that why we all started riding in the first 
place? Are these bikes for me? No, probably not but I'm not going to shit 
on some guy for buying something that makes him happy. Peace. ﻿
comments.author: Runeguy33

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 I bought a kick ass 2000 buell m2 with aftermarket parts such 
as bigger cams,pro series race kit,forcewinder intake, jetted carb for 
$3,700. I can't see spending $3,000- $3,500 on a new bike with 14.5 hp that 
only goes 70 mph.
comments.author: Mike Brink

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 The guys in the video are talking about how they are an 
American company but they make all their bikes in china?? Crazy.. that 
should be reason to be cautious. I think the bikes "look" cool but I have a 
problem with 14.5 max hp and a top speed of 70mph.
comments.author: Mike Brink

comments.text:
+robert jones Most bike stores are closed on Sunday and Monday for some 
oddball reason. Monday and Tuesday would make more sense. Open on weekends 
would be great if you broke your dirt bike Saturday afternoon in the 
desert. Sunday you could go into town for parts and not lose a day 
riding.I'm pretty sure if you buy one, a crate will arrive and you have to 
put it together yourself. There may be "dealers" with pre-assembled ones 
but not a dealer as we know it. No dealers with a service, sales and parts 
department. It takes money to lease a motorcycle sales facility and the 
pennies these clowns make on this junk will never afford a fully staffed 
sales, service and parts department.Most "dealers" most likely work out of 
their garage.It's not much more than a shady, fly-by-night scam.Like I 
said, there's over 200 manufacturers in China. This is just one. If these 
Chinese bikes were so good, why only one importer here in the states? 
You're throwing money away on these bikes. Buy an old Yamaha SR500, have 
money left over for a spare set of tires and have a fucking ball riding it 
for decades. Get those old SR's before they really appreciate!
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 I contacted the Miami "dealership" and they close on 
weekends. What a joke.
comments.author: robert jones

comments.text:
+Johan Pretorius Oh, there's at least ONE good use for these ChinkCycles:
Biker Parties! "Sledge Hits: 3 for a Dollar!" or maybe dropping them from 
cranes.
Blowing them up with homemade bombs? Running over them with Harleys...the 
list goes on.
There's over 200 motorcycle makers in China today which insures the fact 
that they're all junk.
My choice is Yamaha's XT/TT/SR-series of single cylinder overhead cam four 
strokes. Reliable as anvils. Just not a heavy...

I've been in contact with Scott Colosimo, "President" of CycleWerks and he 
tells me they're made in the USA. He tell me (some) Harleys parts are made 
in China and Harleys in India (partly right)
He's a chronic liar who hope that everyone will believe him.
He just needs to stick to designing vacuum cleaners because he "sucks" as a 
"motorcycle manufacturer".
"Big Boy"? "Johnway"? I'm thinking the "Big Boy" must be a huge seller with 
the limp-wristed set.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 I live in South Africa and we have a lot of Chinese bikes 
here. Big Boy, Johnway, Conti..... the list goes on. They are cheap don't 
know what the Rand(our currency) Dollar is right now, but you can buy them 
for +- $1200. for 125CC and up to $3000 for the 350CC choppers. These bikes 
might look good now, but 4-6 months down the line they look terrible. The 
vibration from the motor makes the screws fall out, speedo and rev counters 
break. If you go to the dealership you will see the workshop is stacked. I 
will never buy these Chinese bikes. I bought a 91 Honda XRV750 Africa Twin 
for less then a 350 china special. It is no contest when it comes to 
quality. Oh and if you want to upgrade from this china bikes don't bother 
selling your old one, just throw it away, it just wont sell.
comments.author: Johan Pretorius

comments.text:
+Runeguy33 It only took you two days to formulate that response? College 
really helped, eh?
Speaking of your "college studies", just where in the hell would you apply 
that science to? I mean, where would you get a job that would require on 
your application, "Iron Age European cultures"? Reminds me of the guy who 
showed up wearing a business suit to apply for a mechanics job at my shop. 
I damn near laughed him out of my office!

If it helps, I keep in personal touch with the president and vice president 
of CycleWerks, Scott and Brett respectively. I just responded to both of 
their personal emails minutes ago as a matter of fact. Give me your 
personal email and I'll forward them to you.

What's a "star" [sic] 950? Is that what Yamaha calls their cruisers now? 
Too ashamed to put "Yamaha" on the tanks?

You go ahead and ride your "star" [sic] 950. I'm sure it's a very reliable 
motorcycle and won't leave you stranded on the side of the road in the 
middle of the night like a lot of these CycleWerks pieces of shit are doing.
I can't "do the same" because I don't OWN a "star [sic] 950". I own Yamahas.

I "know nothing" of those bikes? How do you figure? I've very accurately 
pointed out that they are Chinese imports of extremely low quality. Sure, 
they look good but...

Did you know these are just one of over 200 Chinese-made motorcycles? No? 
That's what I thought.

On closing, I'm thinking of opening a tool manufacturing facility. My tools 
will be fashioned from stone. I would be honored to have you on board what 
with your expertise in "Neolithic" knowledge. We'd make a killing!

You should have known.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
Please don't drink before you reply. I'm "Runeguy33" because of my college 
studies of Neolithic and Iron Age European cultures. Runes are ancient, 
indigenous symbols that stood for letters of the alphabet and in some cases 
full words. 
Your arguments are getting ridiculous. Because you know nothing of these 
bikes that were designed in the middle of the last decade, you've 
substituted reasoning with ignorant racial slurs and personal insults. You 
target people because you assume that they've done even less homework than 
you in order to justify the purchase of whatever mode of transportation you 
have. I noticed that you haven't dated to dispute the claims of people on 
here who have claimed to work for CCW dealers.
It's a beautiful day, so I'm going to abandon this dead end argument and go 
ride my star 950. I recommend you do the same.

Ride safe, and may many happy miles be ahead of you. Peace.
comments.author: Runeguy33

comments.text:
+Runeguy33 What's a "Rune"? That Honda motorsikle nobody bought?
Ever wonder why? "Rune" is pronounced "Ruin". Kinda like Mexicans don't 
drive Chevy Novas. "No va"...."doesn't go". Them Mexicans...comical fuckers.
Rune is actually a poem and bikers generally don't associate with poetry 
unless it's something like:
"Roses are red
Violets are blue
Sugar is sweet, so
Sit on my face!" 
Stuff along those lines.

You should have known.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Runeguy33 You DO realize this isn't the American "Cleveland" 
motorcycle...don't you? If so, more bad news: The Cleveland Motorcycle 
Company went out of business in 1929! (1915-1929)
I'm willing to bet that you still have a better chance of locating parts 
for the American Cleveland motorcycle than the chink one.

You should have known.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Runeguy33 You post a list of "bike shops" that stock parts for a 
motorcycle made in China.
Tomorrow, when I visit Carlson Motosports Inc. I'll be sure to ask, "Do you 
stock Cyclewerks parts?" I'm sure they'll toss me out through the plate 
glass window like Eddie Murphy's "Axel Foley" in Beverly Hills Cop! 
I don't dare ask at the Harley-Davidson dealership. I might join the St. 
Lawrence River Swimming Club!

Seriously, kid. I know. I just retired after 41 years as a mechanic and you 
cannot get parts for kit bikes made in China. You DO realize If you buy 
one, they freight you one in from China...don't you? You don't just ride 
off from a "dealer" with the salesman waving "goodbye" as you roar off to 
the nearest "biker bar"...if it lasts that far...
I realize you're young what with the mention of "mother" and the whimsical 
little face you made of a colon and letter 'p'. Cute, kid. Real cute.
But, trust me. You'd just be throwing away money on one.
Please google this: "Cleveland, nothing but problems: customer critique of 
warranty, manufacture quality and service of Cleveland Cyclewerks".
Trust me. You'll thank me sooner than later.

You should have known.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
When I thought about buying one, I made sure I could get parts. My mother 
didn't raise a foolish son. :p
comments.author: Runeguy33

comments.text:
Really? Have you owned one? Cause you can google CCW parts and there's

comments.author: Runeguy33

comments.text:
+Nathan Fraser You'd ride it a couple hours until it broke. Then, you'd

You can't get parts for them.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
I think they are a Great Idea! And I would ride the one that looks more

comments.author: Nathan Fraser

comments.text:
+Jeff S WTF is "L" omg"?
Anyway, I call it as I see it. No sugar coating here.
Chinky Dinks sending shit bikes over here and suckers buying them.
Remember about 10 years ago you couldn't walk into certain auto parts sores 
w/o tripping over these new, mini crotch rocket "pocket bikes"? Or were you 
too young to get out yet?
Anyway, I was amazed that something that looked so nice and sporty cost 
only about $150. Some zit-faced counter kid saw me pause to look at them 
and he said something along the lines of, "You don't want to buy one of 
those."
Here's a salesman for them, telling me not to buy one! Now, THAT'S bad! 
I, personally have had the mis-pleasure of working on Chink Shit in my 41 
year long career as a mechanic. Some are Honda Industrial GX-series clones. 
Look just like the Hondas but there's a difference.
What some major companies do/did and in Honda's case, they'd sell China 
their old stampings, casting molds and dies...after they'd wear out. 
Really! I was a Honda engine distributor for over 15 years. Also an 
authorized warranty/repair dealership for same. I'm not some idiotic 
YouTube Commando making shit up as  go along as you do, kid.
Yes, you could spend $425 for a Honda GX160 from me or pay $59 for a 
Chinky-Dink clone through Harbor Freight (with coupon) Which one's gonna 
last longer? I have a real GX160 on my wood splitter I bought used in 2000 
and the fucker keeps going. Of course, I service it being I'm smart and all.

If these CycleJerks bikes were actually a top quality bike, I'd refer to 
them as "Communist China Quality, Slave-Labor Produced Motorcycles" but 
they're not.
So, they're "Chink Shit", you fucking Dink!

You should have known. 

Anybody else up for a severe mocking?
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
+Yamaha SR650 Fuck yeah dude, that Sam Eliot. (a chance for you to cry 
more, the "L" omg I'll get you a tissue to dab your weeping crotch with. I 
don't give a fuck how it is spelled, I just figure you're so high on 
yourself you actually hear yourself in his voice)  I agree with you about 
these bikes being a bad purchase but you come off as the biggest fucking 
douche bag to ever post on youtube. maybe if you threw out "chink" and 
"dink" just a little more people would think you were cool, give it a try.

You should have known.
comments.author: Jeff S

comments.text:
+Prodan Vlad Nobody sees to want to let the truth set in: These bikes are 
Chinese, ultra-low quality junk. Parts are not available. There are no 
dealerships. 
If any real, dyed-in-the-wool motorcycle enthusiast knows, as I do, just 
watching this video is a dead giveaway this is some fly-by-night operation. 
Some clown, second-rate actors "hangin' in a bar" with stick-on earring 
studs? C'mon! 
YouTube is the only place these bikes are advertised. Not in Cycle World, 
etc.

For the truth on what's going on with these bikes, go to:
Cleveland, nothing but problems: "Customer critique of warranty, 
manufacture quality and service of Cleveland Cyclewerks"

Again, these bikes are brittle and parts are not available.
The price lone should be a giveaway. You get shipped a bike in a crate and 
you're on your own.
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
For 3000$ you could buy a nice bike used. I bought a used Kawasaki ER5 from 
2000, last year, with 1000 euros, a full revision was another 1000 euros 
and I ride the hell out of that poor bike. I've done 28000 km last year and 
I only had to change the filters and the oil. I can't see the value of a 
cruiser except for the looks, but that it's not going to get you far...

I love the concept and its a cool bike.  I have an old Yamaha 850 Tripple,

comments.author: Ian Thompson

comments.text:
Take some time and look at whats really happening here fellas. These guys 
have a idea and are making moves to service a group of consumers and 
hopefully make some bank while doing it. The bikes they offer are clearly 
throw away bikes styled for yuppie/hipsters to play motorcycle for a summer 
with out having to have the knowledge to maintain a older bike or make a 
major financial investment. These guys are saying "Grab a 3/4 helmet, 
Bubble shield, Levis trucker denim jacket and a pair of converse Chuck 
Taylor lows and you got your Instagram ready biker look to go with you 
3000$ cafe racer". All for under 4 grand!! Its all so clear...Let these 
guys take advantage of people who want to present themselves in a certain 
way for a small period of time and know the kid who carries his skateboard 
around in the shopping mall grows up and his interests change.﻿

comments.text:
Right. Much easier to do adjustments with a pushrod engine. However, 
overhead cams can get you more power. Now for a single, I don't think DOHC 
is necessary, but Honda was the first to use DOHC on a single cylinder 
bike, and now just about every 4-stroke dirtbike is a DOHC. So if you want 
a lighter and slightly more powerful engine, ditch the pushrods.

But really, why even worry about valves and cams in the first place? Just 
buy a 2-stroke and be done with it.
comments.author: Johnny Tobifour

comments.text:
+Johnny Tobifour You move from an easily adjustable rocker arm arrangement 
to bucket and shims etc, the maintenance is more difficult and they are far 
more complex. DOHC on a cheap single cylinder bike is unnecessary ;-)
